Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Adaptive Degradation-Based Prognosis with Application to Vehicular Electrical Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to use real-time performance-/condition-based sensor signals to characterize component-to-component degradation interactions in multi-component systems, and use this characterization to improve sensor-based prognostics of complex engineering systems. The general approach used for modeling component interdependencies within a given system has traditionally focused on investigating the effects that a component's failure has on the remaining surviving components. In contrast, this project's approach addresses this challenge at a much more fundamental level by focusing on the effects of gradual and partial degradation of system components rather than the effects of their failures. This will be achieved through a combined stochastic and statistical modeling framework, which will be used to develop adaptive prognostic models for components with interdependent degradation processes. Deliverables for this project include a software with prognostic algorithms, documentation of research results, validation on industrial platform, and engineering student education.

The success of this project will have a direct impact on improving human safety, and reducing maintenance and warranty costs of the American automotive industry. Specifically, this GOALI project is conducted in close collaboration with General Motors. It aims to apply the prognostic methods on key components of the Vehicular Electric Power Generation and Storage (EPGS) system. Findings of this research will also benefit many other industrial sectors, including the airline industry, the power generation industry, manufacturing sector, and domains of the service sector. The research agenda will serve as the foundation for the doctoral dissertations of two Ph.D. students, providing them with a rich training experience that combines theoretical and industrial work as well as internship opportunities. Research findings will be incorporated in a Prognostics graduate course. Dissemination will include conference presentations to the academic communities as well as industrial seminars and workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research conducted in this project focuses on predicting physical degradation of engineering systems that consist of multiple components. What makes this project unique is that the predictive models capture the interdependencies that take place between components of a given system, i.e., how the degradation of one component impacts (e.g. accelerates) the degradation rate of other components. The contribution of the research conducted in this project can be highlighted by the fact that the existing knowledgebase typically circumvents this challenge by assuming independence between components of a given system. An automotive electric power generation and storage (EPGS) system is utilized as a platform for evaluating and validating the methodology used to develop the predictive models proposed in this research. This was made possible by partnering with the automotive industry and developing a detailed test-rig for conducting accelerated degradation tests and studying degradation interactions between start-stop starters and battery state-of-health; key components of the EPGS system.

The research roadmap included two key degradation-based predictive models that utilized sensor data to capture degradation interactions and predict remaining useful life.  Specifically, two key types of degradation interactions were addressed: discrete and continuous.  Discrete interactions refers to systems where one component of a system accelerates the degradation rate of another component at predetermined degradation states of the former. These states can sometimes be identified using historical data. The second scenario focuses on applications where degradation interactions between components occur on a more continuous basis (the discrete states are not identifiable).  

The success of this project has a direct impact on reducing warranty and maintenance costs for the automotive industry, drive safety, and customer experience by providing advance warning of unexpected functional faults and/or failures of complex systems without being overly conservative on the useful life. Such benefits can be attributed to the improved accuracy in assessing current and future degradation states of the system components. Since the models are generic in nature, additional benefits can be realized in numerous engineering systems across different application domains including manufacturing, energy and power generation assets, and civil structures.
